Authors:
Salma Ouhibi, Carla Santos, Ridha Gali, Celia Soares,
Abderrazzek Hedhili, Russell Paterson, Nelson Lima
Title:
Penicillium tunisiense sp. nov., a novel species of
Penicillium section Ramosa discovered from Tunisian orchard apples
Keywords:
Phylogeny; Taxonomy; β-tubulin; calmodulin; ITS region;
MLSA
Abstract:
One of the limiting factors of commercial orchard apple
production is the short shelf life due to fungal biodeterioration,
including production of mycotoxins such as patulin. Two similar
Penicillium isolates could not be identified as previously described
species in a survey of orchard apples from Tunisia for patulin producing
fungi. These isolates are described as novel species using multilocus
DNA sequence analysis of partial β-tubulin, calmodulin and nuclear
ribosomal internal transcribed spacer regions; and morphological,
physiological and biochemical characters. The isolates were considered
negative for patulin production since the isoepoxydon dehydrogenase
(IDH) gene did not amplified and the compound detected at the same
retention time of patulin (14.9 min) showed a different UV spectrum
using U-HPLC/UV-DAD. In terms of phylogeny, the two isolates clustered
with Penicillium section Ramosa and are closely related to P.
chroogomphum, P. lenticrescens and P. soppii. Furthermore, their macro-
and micro-morphological traits differed from these species. Hence, the
isolates represent a novel species in Penicillium section Ramosa and the
name Penicillium tunisiense sp. nov. is proposed.
